report_text: **institution emergency department patient name: **name[aaa, bbb m] account #: **id-num date of service: **date[mar 03 06] primary care physician: **name[vvv m uuu] history of present illness: chief complaint: back pain. this is a **age[in 30s]-year-old female with a past medical history of chronic back pain. she has no history of trauma. her back pain has been present in its current state for approximately the last three weeks without resolution. the patient has a difficulty finding a comfortable position with which to sit in to relieve her pain and tends to be writhing around searching for pain relief. the pain is mid-back in location, occasionally radiates down her left leg, but has lead to no weakness or numbness. the patient does, per herself have some gait instability secondary to this pain. review of systems: constitutional: denies any fever, chills, or night sweats. ent: denies any sore throat, rhinorrhea, or ear pain. eyes: denies any blurry vision or diplopia. respiratory: denies any shortness of breath or wheezing. cardiovascular: denies any chest pain or palpitations. gi: denies any nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation. gu: denies any bowel or bladder problems. neurologic: denies any numbness or tingling. musculoskeletal: per hpi. integument: denies any rashes or hives. psychiatric: denies any mood changes. past medical history: 1. mnire's disease. 2. endometriosis. medications: the patient is not taking any medications. allergies: percocet and iodine. social history: she denies any tobacco and endorses occasional alcohol use. family history: family history is positive for hypertension and coronary artery disease. physical exam: general: the patient was in no apparent distress. vital signs: temperature 37.9, pulse 67, respirations 16, blood pressure 106/48, and the patient is saturating 96% on room air. heent: neck was supple and nontender without evidence of lymphadenopathy. eyes: pupils are equally round and reactive to light. extraocular muscles are intact. respiratory: chest was clear to auscultation bilaterally. cardiovascular: heart had a regular rate and rhythm. gastrointestinal: abdomen was obese, but otherwise flat, soft, and nontender. neurologic: cranial nerves ii through xii were grossly intact. musculoskeletal: the patient had mid-back pain on palpation. it was approximately a 9/10 and nonradiating down her leg. straight leg raise was negative. upon entrance to the room, the patient was sitting forward and achieving comfort through this position. sensation was intact throughout her upper extremities, lower extremities, and trunk to light touch and pinprick. ed course: the patient was seen and examined by myself and by my attending, dr. **name[zzz]. she was given 30 mg of iv toradol for pain relief and we ordered an x-ray of the spine to rule out degenerative spondylolisthesis. the patient's x-ray was read as normal and she was discharged to home with follow-up instructions with dr. **name[ttt] who she has seen in the past for similar back pain issues. she was given a prescription for an mri of the lumbar spine to rule out spinal stenosis. it was felt that this could be the cause of her pain judged by her relief from sitting forward. disposition: disposition to home and prescriptions given for flexeril 10 mg p.o. t.i.d. p.r.n. muscle spasm and motrin 600 mg p.o. follow-up instructions: the patient is to follow up with her pcp as soon as she can and also with dr. **name[ttt] who she had an appointment with next thursday.
